statement.p: An aircraft in flight has total energy given by \displaystyle{E}_{{T}}=\frac{{1}}{{2}}{m}{v}^{{2}}+{m}{g}{h} where
\displaystyle{m} is the mass of the aircraft in pounds
\displaystyle{h} is the height above sea level in feet

Suppose a glider with mass \displaystyle{1015} lbs and initial velocity \displaystyle{84} ft/s is at an altitude of \displaystyle{8},{500}. ft MSL. If the glider forces a descent to \displaystyle{8},{363} ft MSL, what must the new velocity be? ft/s
Round according to the rules for measurements.
Hint: The total energy will be the same before and after the altitude change.

solution.p: The total energy will be the same for the speed \displaystyle{84} ft/s and for the new speed, so we calculate total energy first.

\displaystyle{E}_{{T}}=\frac{{1}}{{2}}{\left({1015}\right)}{\left({84}\right)}^{{2}}+{\left({1015}\right)}{\left({32.1740}\right)}{\left({8},{500}.\right)}={281162105}. Note this has 2 sigfigs, because of the velocity.
Next we setup the same equation for the new altitude using \displaystyle{E}_{{T}} from above.
